title: Celebs flock to Florida for launch of world-first guitar-shaped hotel
text:
Guitar hotel opening was attended by the A listers (Picture: Rex/Mega)

Khloe Kardashian, Johnny Depp and Morgan Freeman have flocked to Florida to check out the world’s first guitar-shaped hotel, the Seminole Hard Rock Hotel and Casino.

The hotel started renovations over three years ago and poured in $1.5 billion (£1.2 billion) to the construction of the unique building, which now boasts 36 storeys and 638 rooms.

Celebrities showed their support at the official opening on Thursday evening, taking to social media to express their praise.

Khloe posted a series of photos of herself to Instagram with the cryptic caption: ‘Forgot how muggy it gets in Florida’, as well as two snake emojis.

While actor Joe Manganiello posted a photo of himself, alongside Morgan Freeman, Johnny Depp and Joe Perry, with the caption: ‘Great times last night at the @hardrockholly Guitar Hotel opening’.

(From left) Morgan Freeman, Johnny Depp, Joe Perry and Joe Manganiello (Picture: REX)

Bella Thorne rocking it out at Hard Rock Hotel launch (Picture: MEGA)

Sofia Richie stuns in beachy loungewear look (Picture: REX)

Khloe Kardashian rocks up on the Hard Rock Hotel red carpet (Picture: REX)

Johnny Depp and Joe Magniello are all attitude at the Hard Rock Hotel launch (Picture: MEGA)

Scott Disick is a Hard (Rock) egg to crack a smile on the red carpet (Picture: REX)

Views of The World’s first guitar-shaped hotel, which opens this week in Hollywood, Florida (Picture: MEGA)

YouTube star Bella Thorne documented her stay at the hotel with a small collection of photos and videos, including her lounging by the pool.

In one video, she takes a video selfie and then turns the camera around to show a beautiful pool, with the caption: ‘So much fun, there’s even a water slide! Hard Rock’.

In another few videos, she shows a fire and stage show by the pool, as well what the guitar looks like lit up at night.

On Friday, Maroon 5 is set to take the stage as the first act in the newly renovated 7,000-seat Hard Rock Live.

Last year, Seminole Gaming CEO Jim Allen told the Sun Sentinel that his intention was to rival Las Vegas and Atlantis in the Bahamas.

‘We could have easily just built some rectangular building…but the (Seminole) tribe is once again trying to create something that is iconic, that creates international tourism coming to Florida,’ Jim said.

‘We truly believe the design alone will create additional tourism,’ he added.
